Article.ArticleTitle: Atmospheric Factors Affecting a Decrease in the Night-Time Concentrations of Tropospheric Ozone in a Low-Polluted Urban Area.

AbstractText: Ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) decomposition in the troposphere is a very important process which prevents excessive O<sub>3</sub> accumulation in the air. It is particularly significant on warm summer days which are marked by a high risk of photochemical smog. We used Spearman's rank correlation test to determine relationships between the drop in O<sub>3</sub> concentrations over time (-ΔO<sub>3</sub>), nitrogen oxide (NO), nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>), and total nitrogen oxide (NO<sub>x</sub>) concentrations and meteorological factors (1-h average) in low-polluted urban area in Olsztyn (north-eastern Poland). Nitrogen oxide concentrations were measured continuously by the chemiluminescence method, and O<sub>3</sub> concentrations were determined by the UV photometric method. The obtained results suggest that the rate of decomposition of tropospheric O<sub>3</sub> is affected mostly by the presence of NO<sub>x</sub>, high temperature, and air humidity (positive correlation) as well as by wind speed (negative correlation). Maximum correlation coefficient values were reported between -ΔO<sub>3</sub> and air temperature, -ΔO<sub>3</sub> and absolute air humidity when NO<sub>x</sub> concentrations were low (below 1.0 microgram per cubic meter), reaching 0.271 and 0.243, respectively. These results indicate that O<sub>3</sub> also reacted with air components other than NO and NO<sub>2</sub>. Precipitation at average temperature of < 0 °C did not significantly contribute to a drop in O<sub>3</sub> concentrations at night-time. In the warm season, precipitation slowed down the rate of O<sub>3</sub> decomposition, mostly because NO<sub>x</sub> were scrubbed by rain. An analysis of seasonal and daily -ΔO<sub>3</sub> fluctuations revealed that -ΔO<sub>3</sub> values were highest in the summer and shortly after sunset in the diurnal cycle.
